history.content: As someone who took EE 16A, CS 61A, and Math 53 together in the same semester, I'd rank EE 16A's workload to be similar to CS 61A and a fair amount larger than Math 53. EE 16A focuses largely on linear algebra and proofs, two concepts that can be relatively challenging when applying them for the first time, and circuits (especially the labs) also tend to be fairly time-consuming to understand. CS 61A, on the other hand, is more conceptually intuitive once you get the hang on programming, while Math 53 is often just plug-and-chug of equations into different problem types (at least, my semester was taught somewhat like that). Because of that added rigor, I'd estimate EE 16A to be perhaps 1.5-2x the workload of CS 61A if you've done programming before, but maybe a similar workload if you haven't. Personally (I've programmed before, though), I spent maybe 5-10 hours outside class/discussion/lab for EE 16A, 3-6 hours for CS 61A, and 1-2 hours for Math 53, but that was just me.

children.subject: Approximately 2/3 of ee16a is linear algebra, so if you have taken 54, it should be easy to go through that part. The other 1/3 is circuit. I personally took 16a with 170,188,and 61c. Among all those courses, 16a was the easiest. 47D will have you complete the circuit part only, and therefore you could potentially lose a chance to get higher grades in linear algebra part to compensate any loss in the circuit part. Nevertheless, 16a has a good grade distribution and historically more than half of the class get an A/A+

I took ee16a with Sahai and 61b with Hilfinger concurrently. The class is very hard if you have no idea about linear algebra, despite the staff saying otherwise (my case). I have some friends who took the class with me (mostly MechE and EECS) and even the ones that had taken 54 a couple semesters ago found it relatively easy

I think the class is very worthwhile and that if you understood 54 I guess that you can get a lot out of it with little effort. So yes, you should feel ok with taking the class concurrently with 61b. By the way the labs are amazing and in my opinion the most important part of the course. I found that many concepts in the class did not really click for me until I hit the lab. Also the Trilateration GPS lab is awesome and if well studied will give you a very good understanding about how to make nice models that try to explain the world

So based off of the answer given above, if one took Math 54, how manageable/easy would EE16A be? Especially if one is taking it with CS61B (hilfinger)? Would I just be better off taking EE47D (which doesn't have the lab requirement. Just homeworks, Midterm 2, and the Final)

history.content: What is its workload compared to classes such as CS61A and Math 53/54?
